fields.label_text:
103-6

The Makers of Simple Furniture was a short-lived company run by Summers during the 1930s producing innovative designs which exploited the strength of plywood. Inspired by and comparable to Alvar Aalto's bent plywood chairs from the same decade (shown in the bay to the right), Summers' chair achieved an integration of design and manufacture similar to Aalto's designs. The production process required no heat or steam, but relied on the veneers being glued together and held in place in a mould for eight hours.

ARMCHAIR
Designed by Gerald Summers (British, 1899-1967)
Made by the Makers of Simple Furniture Ltd, London
Seven layers of plywood moulded in a single sheet
About 1934

This chair was inspired by Alvar Aalto's bent plywood chairs from the same decade and achieved an integration of design and manufacture similar to Aalto's designs. The production process required no heat or steam, but relied on the veneers being glued together and held in place in a mould for eight hours.

W.26-1978

Armchair
1934
Gerald Summers (1899–1967)

England 
Manufactured before 1939 by Makers of Simple Furniture, London
Moulded 13-ply birch plywood

Museum no. W.26-1978

For this chair, 13 veneer sheets were stacked, each sheet with its grain running at a perpendicular angle to the next. Cuts were made for the arms and back legs, then glue spread between each layer. The stack of sheets was pressed between a two-part wooden mould for eight hours. Finally, the front legs were cut out from the fully moulded board.

fields.descriptive_line: Armchair, 1934. Designed by Gerald Summers, manufactured before 1939 by Makers of Simple Furniture, London. Moulded 13-ply birch plywood
fields.physical_description:
Curvilinear shaped armchair formed of a stack of moulded 13-ply birch plywood.

13 veneer sheets were stacked, each sheet with its grain running at a perpendicular angle to the next. Cuts were made for the arms and back legs, then glue spread between each layer. The stack of sheets was pressed between a two-part wooden mould for eight hours. Finally, the front legs were cut out from the fully moulded board.
fields.dimensions: Height: 74 cm Seat height 33.5 cm, Width: 60.3 cm, Depth: 85 cm

fields.location: Furniture, room 135, case BY10, shelf EXP
fields.public_access_description:
This chair's very clever, simple design allows it to be made from a single sheet of plywood. Designed in 1934 by Gerald Summers and manufactured by his London company, The Makers of Simple Furniture, the chair is made from a plywood sheet consisting of 13 layers of cross-grained veneer. The sheet was first cut with four straight lines, which outlined the position and width of the arms and back legs. While the glue between the plys was still wet, the sheet was then pressed in a wooden mould for eight hours. The mould articulated the curve of the chair's legs and arms, leaving only the front legs to be cut out after the moulding process was finished. 

The construction of the chair from a single piece of moulded board gives it a highly distinctive visual and structural clarity. Summers was one of a group of European designers working in the early 1930s to push the formal and structural limits of new furniture materials such as plywood.
fields.bibliography: Architectural Review, September, 1939, p.141 All things bright and beautiful, Fiona MacCarthy British Design since 1880, Fiona MacCarthy Journal of Design History, Vol. 5, no. 3, 1992, Gerald Summer and makers of Simple Furniture, Martha Deese. 100 Masterpieces from the Vitra Design Museum Collection, edited by Alexander von Vegesack, Peter Dunas and Mathias Schwartz-Clauss, 1996, pp.110f.
fields.history_note:
Summers' own furniture company, Makers of Simple Furniture Ltd. (founded in 1929), produced only 120 examples of this chair. Despite constructive advantages, the production costs of the chair and subsequently the sales price were quite high (especially higher than the then popular Scandinavian designs).

Historical significance: This chair is an example of the ideal unity of material, production and form. The simple construction dispenses with connectors and almost no off-cuts, using one single sheet of plywood. Following a simple pattern which separates the back legs from the back and armrests, the segments were bent in different directions resulting in an organically shaped armchair that is comfortable even without a cushion.
fields.production_note: Attribution note: small production of about 120
